awd_titl_txt: Facilitating Widespread Implementation of Teaching Strategies Known to Promote Student Success throughout a State System of Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by promoting widespread use of evidence-based, equitable teaching practices that promote learning, success and persistence for our students, particularly those from historically excluded groups. Equipping diverse STEM graduates with the knowledge, critical thinking skills, and problem-solving skills to address complex societal challenges like climate change is critical for sustainable growth and development of our economy and democratic society. The challenge addressed by this grant is that STEM educators receive very rigorous post-graduate training in their disciplines but little to no pedagogical training, leaving them to rely on traditional lecture approaches that have been shown to be less effective in driving student learning or retention in STEM majors. This Level 1 Institutional and Community Transformation IUSE grant will develop and evaluate the impact of a professional development program that targets a state school system: the State University of New York (SUNY) system, which is the largest state system of post-secondary schools in the US. The project provides effective training and support for faculty in the use of teaching strategies that improve the success and persistence of their students, particularly from traditionally underserved social groups. The project is building on the success of two national professional development programs that are joining forces to provide three tiers of training and support to faculty in the SUNY system. This  project will focus on a subset of schools that are geographically distributed across the SUNY system, which have built connections and momentum as part of a SUNY-system pilot grant in 2019-2020. Participants in the project will take part in training and community groups to support their adoption of innovative teaching practices. 

The goal of this project is to leverage the connections within the SUNY school system to accelerate diffusion of inclusive, evidence-based instructional practices (EBIPs). The project intends to employ three important levers for change – professional development, agents of change, and communities of support (Laursen et al., 2019) – to accelerate adoption of high impact practices (HIPs) already occurring within pockets in this system. As part of the proposed activities, the first cohort of faculty will take part in three levels of training and support designed to maximize the likelihood that they will adopt one of three HIPs: project-based learning (PBL), course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) or vertically integrated projects (VIPs). Two nationally prominent professional development programs – the Mobile Summer Institutes on Scientific Teaching (MoSI) and the Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities (SENCER) - will provide general training in the implementation of EBIPs. Participants will receive specific training in implementation of one of the three HIPS by local change agents who have successfully deployed these strategies. Finally, participants will join a faculty mentoring network (FMN) of their peers and two expert leaders who will provide support and guidance as they begin the process of implementing HIPs on their own campuses. This longer-term support through community is emerging as an important lever to promote full adoption of innovative teaching strategies. Participation in the project training programs will be tracked and changes in teaching beliefs and behaviors will be measured to determine the efficacy of this approach in fostering widespread change in teaching. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Systemic inequities in the US, like health-care disparities between ethnic groups, for example, are the result, in part, of a healthcare workforce that does not look like the population that it serves.  Systemic inequities in STEM higher education contribute to national inequities by excluding women and other historically marginalized groups from STEM-related workforces.  

This project is the first part of a multi-stage project to address this problem. The long-term goal of the project is to promote adoption of inclusive, active, collaborative teaching practices in the SUNY system of schools, one of the largest and most diverse college systems in the U.S.  In this project, to begin the journey toward our long term goal, we planned to develop and pilot three training workshops for current and future faculty that would help them implement research-backed teaching strategies to improve the effectiveness and equity of their education programs. We also planned to develop customized community support programs to support participants as they begin to implement these strategies in their classrooms. Finally, we planned to start building cross-institutional community in order to provide system-wide awareness of these efforts and support for faculty who commit to making our educational experiences more effective and equitable. In addition to developing these programs, we are evaluating the impact of our programs to better understand how to effectively support participants so that they may fully implement strategies that they learn during the workshops.

Over the two-year period of the grant, we developed and piloted three different pedagogy programs with 50 current and future faculty from 10 SUNY schools.  We also developed and piloted three community support programs that were customized to each workshop. Based on post-workshop surveys, participants overwhelmingly valued the workshops and felt that the experience improved their knowledge, attitudes and skills related to the teaching strategies addressed during the workshop. During the community support sessions, participants reported on their successes and challenges while attempting to implement strategies and formed cross-institutional relationships and connections. Seventy-five percent of the respondents to an end-of-program survey reported on various ways that they had implemented strategies from the workshop.  

To continue progress toward our long-term goal, our project team submitted a grant proposal for the next stage of the project in July 2024. If funded, we will deploy the programs that we developed and piloted during this project broadly across the SUNY system to increase the impact of our programs. As we continue to evaluate and research the outcomes of this expanded deployment, we will better understand the barriers that thwart adoption of effective, equitable teaching practices in higher education that will inform the efforts to drive the same change at other institutions of higher education in the U.S.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2024
Modified by: Michelle D Withers
